options.text: The transition metals and their compounds are known for their catalytic activity due to their ability to adopt multiple oxidation states and to form complexes.

Interstitial compounds are those that are formed when small atoms like <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math> or <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi></math> are trapped inside the crystal lattices of metals.

The oxidation states of chromium in <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msubsup><mi>CrO</mi><mn>4</mn><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>−</mo></mrow></msubsup></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>Cr</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msubsup><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mn>7</mn><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>−</mo></mrow></msubsup></math> are not the same.

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>Cr</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>+</mo><mfenced><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">d</mi><mn>4</mn></msup></mfenced></math> is a stronger reducing agent than <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msup><mi>Fe</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><mfenced><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">d</mi><mn>6</mn></msup></mfenced></math> in water.

solution.text:
Chromate CrO4-2⇒ oxidation state =+6
dichromate Cr2O7-2⇒ =+6 oxidation state are same.
